positive.review:
This game makes me wish steam had more than just upvotes and downvotes.

In short yes, the game is super fun. If you like difficult games and don't mind sinking a lot of hours in, reading the wiki or watching Youtube tutorials, then this is the game for you. You can get it on sale for super cheap and I've played this game along with the together version and will continue to do so.

The problem is that the game doesn't tell you how to do anything. Don't get me wrong, it's fun to figure stuff out on your own. But how am I supposed to know that giving meat to a bird in a bird cage enables me to make amazing new food or that bunnymen will attack you just because of you holding meat items, causing me to die 15+ hours into my run. I know dying, learning from your mistakes and starting over is the whole point of the game, but it can get frustrating and repetitive.

Also certain parts of the game like the adventure/story mode are poorly designed in my opinion. It's running around searching for random items on your map for 4 levels, just for you to die on level 5 because you didn't know the final level was in total darkness.

Reading the wiki, watching Youtube tutorial and using mods like display food values, geometric placement, craft pot and minimap feel like necessities for me to enjoy this game.
Classic Survival Game. I'm biased towards this one over Together as it actually has an end goal.

10/10, amazing game!
Amazing game, it is definitely worth buying.

Cute, Tim Burtonesque morbid survival game with all manner of customisable elements like spawn rates for all enemies as well as resources and many more. Play on your own terms. This and Oxygen Not Included are absolute gems whether you like hardcore survival or easy, mind-relaxing sandbox games <3

Easy to get started for non-gamers.  Entertaining. Though I've only played 8 hours on steam I have played a lot on my nintendo switch and love that it remains challenging even hours and hours in.  The fact that you need to start overif you lose keeps you on your toes!

It's creepy, chaotic, and WAY more addictive than I expected.

Don‚Äôt Starve surprised me with how well it blends whimsical art with grounded survival mechanics. The atmosphere is incredible, the survival loop is addictive, and the game still holds up after all these years. Combat is the weakest part, but everything else pulled me in. For the price, it‚Äôs absolutely worth it.

The Good:
‚Ä¢ Amazing Tim Burton-style art and quirky tone
‚Ä¢ Strong survival loop with great early-game pacing
‚Ä¢ Realistic mechanics that actually matter (fire spreading, sanity, sleep)
‚Ä¢ Weather, darkness, and nightfall create genuine tension
‚Ä¢ Lots to discover and experiment with
‚Ä¢ Time flies, easy to get absorbed

The Not-So-Good:
‚Ä¢ Combat feels basic and predictable
‚Ä¢ Early sanity confusion until you understand the system
‚Ä¢ Building in a 2.5D space can feel a little awkward
‚Ä¢ Requires trial-and-error before things start to really click

Final Verdict: 7.5/10

One of the better survival games out there if you like creepy whimsy and grounded mechanics. Combat needs work, but the atmosphere and loop are excellent.

My Recommendation:
At full price ($11.49 CAD), it‚Äôs easily worth it.
On sale? Even better.
If you like crafting survival games with a creepy twist, you should try it.
It's a great game I recommend it for players who like adventure and fast and also slow gameplay. It was 100% worth the money

A really good game. I honestly like this better than Don't Starve Together, because the plot feels more cohesive. The atmosphere has a specific, deadly vibe that's more pronounced than the later sequel.

Overall, it's pretty good! ( À∂ÀÜÍí≥ÀÜÀµ )
Really fun and endless replayability!
I was playing the game since the biggining, i had a non official verion, but it was so good, so nice to play i bought the orginal
Fun graphics, amusing gameplay, and definitely a challenge to survive! Had to look a few things up, but I like that -- the game doesn't hold your hand. Every day I don't starve feels like a victory.
Fun and addicting for sure! It's a challenge for sure.
good game. I recommand it.but i still feel like that this game must e played with reign of the giants with it as a must. the other dlcs are optioanl.
Very engaging open-world survival game with interesting items to craft and find. Highly addictive!
A game with a unique atmosphere, that I honestly cannot say I have seen before or since. You won't regret trying it, especially because the price is reasonable (8,19 Euro at time of writing).
An Amazing game. But you can buy don't starve together it's quite the same but with more features

It's frustrating at first when you die many times, especially when you miss-click during a fight, but after you learn how to avoid danger it's a pretty easy game. Might even get repetitive after I'm done exploring. Very cute design. I love the ghosts, beefalo and pumpkin lantern design the most.
Absolutely love the art style of this game along with the survival aspect of the game. I enjoy all the different characters and each of their personalities.
One of the best games ever. Also I really recommend the dlcs as well! Such a good game love and yeah. It's great.
challenging but satisfying to learn how to survive and stay sane in game :) love the creepy vibes

I've had this game for a while and it's only recently I've played it. While I love my cozy games, this one takes survival cozy to a whole new level. It does challenge your problem solving and inventory management plus it's a really great game to play during spooky season!

Honestly, the game is superb! It's an open world survival game where we need to scavenge, chop, build and craft survival items, build a campfire to stay safe at nights and keep ourselves well fed. We need to keep an eye on those three meters of our overall health including sanity, health and stomach. It's a solo player exploration immersive experience, Recommended if you loves survival + open world + crafting games, Great job Klei Entertainment üíó
Stressful, but fun. Nice little spooky world and rules to discover.

Fun if you know what you're getting into. Very down and dirty survival game that picks up fast once you get hold of the mechanics. Would definitely recommend using/following the wiki though, since otherwise the learning curve can be very steep (unless you enjoy that, then more power to you!)

this game is everything a survival game should be but with a interesting twist to most aspects. me and my kids love playing this together the more ppl to play with the better but you can also find people to make teams with. lots of fun to be had
Don't Starve is one of the best games in my library its fun hard and has a grand story its really good

Might just be biased to survival games, but very very fun! Characters are easy to grow fond of, mechanics are simple and it's interesting to figure out each characters different "things" that separate them individually. Don't listen to me too hard, I rely heavily on cheats, but you have to pretend I didn't say that.
Honestly, I love the whole game. The graphics,the animation, the creativity, the lore. It's amazing! It reminds me of Edgar Allen Poe's work, but not really at the same time.
I've played this game on EVERYTHING since it came out. Switch,laptop,mobile. Ive played all of the dlcs. I love this game
It's one of those games like Terraria where you don't know what you're doing for a while, and then everything just clicks and you can't stop playing.
An awesome game, with awesome DLCs. BUY THE BUNDLE you will not be regret about it.
not shitty, cut ten thousand trees night brings sweat dripping, my  ghost sis tanks hits revives can't fu^^ wit me, light torch  to fight forest, deerclops will go missing
Great and classic survival game

I‚Äôve spent some time with this game and honestly, it surprised me in a way I didn‚Äôt fully expect. I don‚Äôt want to sound dramatic, but there‚Äôs something oddly satisfying about how everything fits together ‚Äî not in some perfect, polished ‚Äúadvertisement‚Äù way, but more like a game that knows exactly what it wants to be and just‚Ä¶ goes for it.

The first thing I noticed is the atmosphere. Every part of the game ‚Äî the visuals, the sound, the pacing ‚Äî kind of blends into this feeling that you‚Äôre actually inside its world, even if you‚Äôre just casually playing. I know that sounds a bit clich√©, but it‚Äôs true. Sometimes it‚Äôs chaotic, sometimes slow, sometimes you‚Äôre just wandering around thinking ‚Äúok, what now?‚Äù but that‚Äôs honestly part of the charm. The game doesn‚Äôt try to rush you unless it actually needs to.

Gameplay-wise, it has this mix of familiar elements and small twists that keep things from feeling stale. Nothing groundbreaking, maybe, but it all works together in a way that feels natural. There were moments when I thought ‚Äúyeah, I‚Äôve seen this in other games,‚Äù but then the game throws in tiny details or unexpected interactions that make it stand out just enough. It‚Äôs the kind of thing you only notice after a few hours, when you start connecting the dots.

Performance has been mostly fine. A little rough spot here and there, but honestly, show me a game these days that doesn‚Äôt have something weird happening once in a while. Nothing game-breaking on my end, at least. You can clearly tell the developers put effort into this, even if a few edges are still a bit sharp. Again ‚Äî part of the charm.

What I really appreciate is that the game gives you space to play the way you want. Some people will rush through every objective, others will take their time exploring or messing around, and both approaches actually feel valid. I like games that don‚Äôt punish you for not following some ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù path.

Overall, I‚Äôd say this is one of those titles that grows on you the longer you play. It doesn‚Äôt try too hard to impress in the first five minutes ‚Äî instead it slowly builds its identity, layer by layer, until you suddenly realize you‚Äôve been playing way longer than you planned. If you‚Äôre looking for something that balances comfort with challenge, familiar mechanics with fresh touches, and a world that‚Äôs just fun to be in, then I genuinely think this one is worth giving a shot.

Would I recommend it?
Yeah, I would ‚Äî maybe not to everyone, because no game is for everyone, but definitely to anyone who likes getting lost in a game for a bit and discovering things at their own pace.

Don't Starve is one of the grown up survival games that has it place in my heart since the very beginning more then ten years ago.

You can choose between several characters that have their individual advantages and disadvantages while playing the game. The main goal is to reach Maxwell's Door and go through the story.
Or just survive as long as you can and fight the different Giants that might appear in the seasons the game has.

I most played offline, so the hours I spent are much more than shown in steam (I would say about 500hrs?). 
The game is still unique and very special. I like it most, because it is not mainstream and has its own style and feeling.
Nothing is explained and the player needs to figure out everything by themselves.

Interesting to mention is, that you can create your own rules for the world that is created and define what you want to have appeared less or more like certain giants or certain resources.

There are some basic mechanics the game has, which the player needs to understand:

Hunger - your character needs to eat from time to time

Sanity - you need to do something for the brain of your character to get not insane, otherwise the shadow hands and shadow creatures will appear that attack the character

Health - the environment, the creatures, some consumable and too hot or too cold circumstances can heart the character

Light - the light is the protection against the shadow creatures and the player needs to stay in light to prevent beeing attacked by them and losing sanity

Temperature - not visible directly, but it can be too hot or too cold and the player needs to do something to protect against heat and cold by wearing certain clothes or hats or by staying near a fire

Crafting - one base mechanic is to craft things and structures out of the resources (not all are renewable) one found in the environment

Research - you can upgrade your gear and your base buildings by finding the right resources for it and you will need to to survive over time

The fun part is the challenge the game offers to the player. You have a lot of stress the first runs to survive the harsh environment and to understand the game mechanics.
After meeting the first giants you will get a more deep understanding, what survival means, when the burning sun in summer or the shadow creatures that appear when you lost sanity in spring because the frequent rain depleted your sanity didn't kill you until then.

And this is only tip of the iceberg.
There is Adventure Mode in the Story Mode which gives you different gameplay compared to the bare survival
There are different Giants that appear in different seasons
There are the caves you can jump in
There are the add-ons that give almost a completely different gameplay:
 - Shipwrecked with islands to hop over
 - Hamlet with Pig Villages
 - Reign Of Giants with a lot of extra resources and stuff to encounter
And much more

If you like unique survival games with well balanced game mechanics and crafting, you might like this game and I recommend it to you.
If you do not want to learn a lot and you really don't like to start over and over again at the beginning, you might avoid this game.

At the end, Klei Entertainment made it to stay to their uniqe style of games and this counts a lot nowadays in my humble opinion.

if you're into randomly dying because you forgot to build a fire on time, or had a pack of wild dogs descend upon you before you were prepared to fight them off, this is the game for you! in all honesty, it's a fun game. learning to forage, building stuff and trying not to die.
Watch gameplay before you buy it so you know what you are getting into. It's good if it's what you want
very fun funny little game that still holds up after a bajillion years.... wonderful art direction and wonderful gameplay its super addictive and a good way to spend your time

I recently got into this because of the cameos of certain weapons and monsters in Terraria, and BOY have I been missing out. The thing I truly respect about this game is that instead of making itself accessible to appeal to as many people as possible, it decided to stick to its own identity in spite of pandering to a mainstream audience.

Something you should take note is that this game WILL kick your butt on your first few runs, and you will constantly be on edge as you'll never truly feel safe at any given moment. The game was intentionally designed to be vague and let players figure out how things are done for themselves. (For the most part, anyway.) Though this can either be a good or a bad thing depending on who you ask. Myself, I'd say I'm somewhere down the middle. While I appreciate the game not shoving tutorials in my face, it can lead to some parts being confusing and you're always second guessing whether you're doing something right or not. If you truly want to optimize everything you do, a wiki is practically a requirement.

Still, I admire the balls Klei had when they stuck to their guns and designed the game they way they did even if it might drive certain players away. That's not something you usually see from a lot of games nowadays. Sacrificing universal appeal for the sake of keeping the game cohesive.

If you haven't already, pick this game up. The lack of direction at the start my be daunting for newcomers, but once you get the hang of how the game works, it's satisfying as hell.

Even after 51 hours played of this game, I can barely manage to survive winter. Quite chaotic if you have ADHD like me, you'll forget you need any light source at night, will probably lose track of time trying to hunt a butterfly for food, and you will probably start a fight with something you shouldn't have. 10/10 experience 

Jokes aside, I really enjoy this game probably more than the Don't Starve Together one (no friends to play with). It's got amazing art, very interesting mechanics, lovely music you can vibe to, and hours of content that I promise you won't get tired of (seen people with more than 1k hours on this game)

I can't beat this game. It is long, it is punishing, it is confusing. I ADORE IT. Despite not being able to wrap my mind around how to WIN, the gameplay itself is a fun challenge. I love the art style and the tidbits of hidden lore throughout, and I've enjoyed both this solo version and the co-op version with my siblings. Just a really cool game. 

Getting back on after years of not playing to see if my brain cells have connected and I can finally figure out how to beat this thing. I'll have fun either way. Wish me luck.

First, let me preface that my playthrough was without any of the DLC. I do own all of the DLC for this game, but I decided since it was my first time giving the single-player version a proper shot, I'd play it vanilla. No Hamlet, no Shipwrecked, not even Reign of Giants. Despite that though, I still had a very fun time with the game! I love the sketchy Burton-esque art style and the way the world is set up both on a technical and thematic level, with the use of 2D sprites and rigs not only giving the game a unique look, but an opportunity to sell the world as a stage-play, which I think it does very well.

In terms of gameplay, Don't Starve is very unforgiving. That's the point. The game will rarely, if ever, have something that has no downside. Almost everything has a cost attached to it and if you're not adequately prepared beforehand, the game will punish you. Sitting in the dark? It hurts you! Hoarding food? It'll spoil and become inedible. Made your base around the pigs for protection from enemies? They'll turn into "warepigs" during full moons and start attacking you. This style of gameplay is a very acquired taste and it's understandable if it's not your thing. This uncompromising style of gameplay makes Don't Starve a much more intense survival game than something like Minecraft, since things can and will go wrong at any time.

Surviving for long periods of time before death or regenerating your world will level you up and unlock additional characters. These characters have their own quirks that make them separate from the default character, Wilson. Willow, for example, has a lighter and is completely immune to fire damage. Webber is friendly with the spiders, but the pigs will attack him. Wendy has her twin sister, Abigail, who is a ghost. The game has this hostile world mixed with a twisted sense of humour and I love it for that, it adds a lot of personality to the game beyond it just being hard.

Lastly, I'd like to discuss Adventure Mode. Don't Starve has a story you can complete, but unlike modern survival games that integrate their story into the world, the story in DS is kept separate and doesn't interact with regular survival in any way. In Adventure Mode, you must complete 5 levels of increasing difficulty, culminating in the final level with permanent darkness. If you do make it through all of these levels, you'll come face to face with the supposed villain, Maxwell, and free him from his prison, ending adventure mode and the plot of Don't Starve. I don't enjoy Adventure Mode much. It culminates into running around looking for the pieces to continue onto the next level, over and over again. It gets boring quick. I think how modern survival games approach plot is much, much better.

Overall, very fun game, if a bit lacking in a few areas, but the DLC and sequel fix those issues, so I can't complain too much.

This game makes me wish steam had more than just upvotes and downvotes.

In short yes, the game is super fun. If you like difficult games and don't mind sinking a lot of hours in, reading the wiki or watching Youtube tutorials, then this is the game for you. You can get it on sale for super cheap and I've played this game along with the together version and will continue to do so.

The problem is that the game doesn't tell you how to do anything. Don't get me wrong, it's fun to figure stuff out on your own. But how am I supposed to know that giving meat to a bird in a bird cage enables me to make amazing new food or that bunnymen will attack you just because of you holding meat items, causing me to die 15+ hours into my run. I know dying, learning from your mistakes and starting over is the whole point of the game, but it can get frustrating and repetitive.

Also certain parts of the game like the adventure/story mode are poorly designed in my opinion. It's running around searching for random items on your map for 4 levels, just for you to die on level 5 because you didn't know the final level was in total darkness.

Reading the wiki, watching Youtube tutorial and using mods like display food values, geometric placement, craft pot and minimap feel like necessities for me to enjoy this game.

For someone who forgets to eat, it's ironic that I love a game that is called "Don't Starve" and because I love playing it that I forget to eat! The game offers multiple delicious monsters to eat and very spooky cold nights! If this game was a person would be Tim Burton, because the vibe is torturing amazing :))
I love playing this game!  Only thing i wish was that the don't starve together was cross platform.

For it's price, even without the constant discounts, it is well worth it.
If you're seeking story, this is the go-to. If you're seeking multiplayer, or just generally more casual content and consistent updates, Don't Starve Together may be more suited, however beware the bosses are not designed for solo.
If you have extra money to spend, buy both! They're both great games!

I love this game, it is scary, addicting and fun. This was my first survival game and all other survival games except for Long Dark and Subnautica felt very stale compared to it. The best is that you can even play it in multiplayer (Don¬¥t starve together). To finish the single player, you need to master everything this game has to offer and it will take some time and patience but it is definitely a fun ride.

I've been playing Don't Starve on and off for many years at this point. I have only good things to say about it. One of the most brutal survival games out there, with a beautiful and unique art style.
Very innovative for the time, a milestone of survival games. High replayability. 8/10

Don't Starve was one of the first few games that I bought with my own money back when I created my steam account as a kid. This game has given me many fond adolescent memories of summer afternoons screwing around the vast world the game provides. I feel that many people can get a lot of milage out of this game because of its sandbox nature and progression of objectives.

the art style and characters are some of the most iconic parts of this game. I feel that the style has lodged itself in my brain and never left, and the characters themselves have had such a fun impact on other games around it.
Anyway, I would recommend this game to anyone who likes survival sandbox games.

If you like the dark, Tim Burton vibe, you should also understand that a lot of the joy of mastering this game is learning all the mechanics of a very deep and arbitrary game. Like if you notice your Sanity dropping when it rains, anyone would know the parasol item would help. But knowing that you need flower petals, sticks and cut grass to craft a parasol requires learning the game. And learning that you need to capture and then plant butterflies to grow flowers, well, that is what this game is really all about. The satisfaction one gets from mastering a very very deep set of arbitrary rules. One downside is it can be hard to learn, as the things that will kill you are infrequent and require you to start over and repeat the grindy stuff again and again. Would be nice if you could scumsave to learn combat. 7/10. No DLC needed.

honestly at first the game is pretty overwhelming especially when you realise all the things that are meta but in the end it is a lot of fun to play instinctively!! also the art style is super charming and i love the characters and their little quirks it's probably one of the best games i've tried this year
Very fun survival game. Quite challanging though, as of yet I have not survived past winter, nor summer.
good but not great its good for starting new but dst (dont starve together) is much better cause it has ton more stuff in it

Best survival game ever! It's a real challenge to try to survive, and no offense to whoever's reading this if they like Don't starve together, but I like this game better than Don't starve together! I hope that Klei makes more Don't starve games in the future!
Alright, but a few years ago. Play Don't starve together now, it's an improved and continued experience.

Don't Starve is a brilliant game! The art is absolutely stunning, there is a an interesting story behind it and the gameplay is perfect. Even the music is great, it is not annoying in any way. I love all the interesting characters and all the funny animals in it. Easily my favourite game.
Great game.  Should have reviewed it a long time ago, but whatever.  Here now, dropping my coin in the bucket.

negative.review:
I have conflicting feelings about this game.

I played Don't Starve Together for 300+ hours before getting this one. Fell in love with it. Got this game hoping to also get the Hamlet DLC. But the difference between DST and Don't Starve is JARRING.

I really like both games, but the crafting menu in DST is far superior. While you can customize the craft bar and search within the crafting menu in DST, here in Don't Starve the crafting menu is clunky and takes time and memorizing what tabs items are in. The world in Don't Starve also feels much more limited compared to DST, and the look is outdated. The negative reviews are unfortunately true in this regard-- they seem to have forgotten and left Don't Starve in lieu of DST.

There's a lot more to do in DST as well and again, nothing new has been added in Don't Starve to make up for that. I suppose if you buy the DLCs for Don't Starve there'll be more for you to do in the game?

I'd say get DST (Don't Starve Together) instead of Don't Starve. Even if DST is multiplayer you can also play alone in a private server of your own choosing. There's a lot more there, and even seasonal stuff. While in DST they have Halloween stuff they don't bother with anything Halloween-themed for Don't Starve. There's much more decor and skins and whatnot in DST as well. There's much more customization with the seasons and monsters, and much more bosses and mobs.
I dont get it. Might be fun but the learning curve is beyond me. Maybe guides would help

I like coming back to this game occasionally, but every time I just get bored as there's no real point to it. The idea is good, but there's no reason to play it beyond the first few season cycles. There is an "end" but it feels slapped on, rather than like its part of the game.

Is a novel idea, but would not recommend playing unless you get it for free.
Not for me. 3/10
FUCKING HATE IT
ah hell nah

It's Don't Starve, the game in itself is pretty fun, but in the interest of being honest, this version is absolute trash. They updated and updated and updated Dont Starve TOGETHER, SO MANY TIMES, and left this version behind in the dust, to the point where if you've played and gotten used to Dont Starve Together, this version just feels like a slow, trashy, alpha version. Not worth buying, at all, considering you can just buy DST and play offline, alone, and have all the new, nice stuff.
Used to love this game, now unendingly disappointed Klei won't provide any updates in favor of Don't Starve Together, which crashes anytime I try to load a world with caves.

Meh.

Pretty graphics, but the game loop boils down to running around collecting stuff in order to craft things - not terribly original nor engaging.

That said, I think the exact same thing about No Man's Sky, so I suspect I'm in a pessimistic minority here.
I dont get it. Might be fun but the learning curve is beyond me. Maybe guides would help

I've played The Forest in the past and the survival game idea is great in itself. However, I dind't like that the player isn't able to go back to a previous save from the game interface (but rather only manually backing up and restoring the save files as a workaround). I have also encountered a bug that made my longest game run unusable.
Buggy game from a developer who focuses on producing more garbage DLC over keeping their games working well.
Discontinued and not worth it game the dlc dont make you wanna play more just save your money to buy: Dont Starve Together

Your hand is not hold for anything, you must learn everything on your own and when the game is as complex as Terraria (but without a Guide to help you), you just have to look up everything in order to actually progress which is unfun!
No matter how many times I come back to this game I just kinda don't get it. I like the style but I feel no sense of a goal

They updated and updated and updated Dont Starve TOGETHER, SO MANY TIMES, and left this version behind in the dust, to the point where if you've played and gotten used to Dont Starve Together, this version just feels like a slow, trashy, alpha version. Not worth buying, at all, considering you can just buy DST and play offline, alone, and have all the new, nice stuff.
Used to love this game, now unendingly disappointed Klei won't provide any updates in favor of Don't Starve Together, which crashes anytime I try to load a world with caves.

Meh.

Pretty graphics, but the game loop boils down to running around collecting stuff in order to craft things - not terribly original nor engaging.

That said, I think the exact same thing about No Man's Sky, so I suspect I'm in a pessimistic minority here.
I dont get it. Might be fun but the learning curve is beyond me. Maybe guides would help

I have conflicting feelings about this game.

I played Don't Starve Together for 300+ hours before getting this one. Fell in love with it. Got this game hoping to also get the Hamlet DLC. But the difference between DST and Don't Starve is JARRING.

I really like both games, but the crafting menu in DST is far superior. While you can customize the craft bar and search within the crafting menu in DST, here in Don't Starve the crafting menu is clunky and takes time and memorizing what tabs items are in. The world in Don't Starve also feels much more limited compared to DST, and the look is outdated. The negative reviews are unfortunately true in this regard-- they seem to have forgotten and left Don't Starve in lieu of DST.

There's a lot more to do in DST as well and again, nothing new has been added in Don't Starve to make up for that. I suppose if you buy the DLCs for Don't Starve there'll be more for you to do in the game?

I'd say get DST (Don't Starve Together) instead of Don't Starve. Even if DST is multiplayer you can also play alone in a private server of your own choosing. There's a lot more there, and even seasonal stuff. While in DST they have Halloween stuff they don't bother with anything Halloween-themed for Don't Starve. There's much more decor and skins and whatnot in DST as well. There's much more customization with the seasons and monsters, and much more bosses and mobs.

I've played The Forest in the past and the survival game idea is great in itself. However, I dind't like that the player isn't able to go back to a previous save from the game interface (but rather only manually backing up and restoring the save files as a workaround). I have also encountered a bug that made my longest game run unusable.
Buggy game from a developer who focuses on producing more garbage DLC over keeping their games working well.
Discontinued and not worth it game the dlc dont make you wanna play more just save your money to buy: Dont Starve Together

I got this on sale, understood nothing and died back to back, then my friend gifted me together version, and I can't refund it too since it's been 2 weeks!

Of course the reason why I didn't like it is not the thing above but rather me not liking the gameplay loop. Your hand is not hold for anything, you must learn everything on your own and when the game is as complex as Terraria (but without a Guide to help you), you just have to look up everything in order to actually progress which is unfun!
No matter how many times I come back to this game I just kinda don't get it. I like the style but I feel no sense of a goal

I like coming back to this game occasionally, but every time I just get bored as there's no real point to it. The idea is good, but there's no reason to play it beyond the first few season cycles. There is an "end" but it feels slapped on, rather than like its part of the game.

Is a novel idea, but would not recommend playing unless you get it for free.
*Mac* Doesn't work at all. Won't start up. Support refused to help and Steam wouldn't refund.
Not for me. 3/10
FUCKING HATE IT
